results:
I have gathered comprehensive information about Polish science fiction writers and their relationship to Dune. Now let me provide a summary of the findings from the web search:

Based on the search results, I can provide you with detailed information about Dune's influence on Polish science fiction writers, particularly focusing on Zajdel, Orbitowski, Dukaj, and Ziemiański.

## Polish Science Fiction Writers and Dune's Influence

### Janusz A. Zajdel (1938-1985)
Janusz Zajdel was a Polish science fiction author and pioneer of sociological science fiction in Poland. The most important Polish literary award in the field of science fiction is named after him. He is recognized as an originator of the social science fiction genre in Polish science fiction, known in Poland as the sociological speculative fiction (fantastyka socjologiczna).

Zajdel presented and studied totalitarian, limited, controlled societies. His novelistic work consisted of dystopian works, proving the impossibility of creating a perfect community through imposed rules from above. Dune by Herbert – Frank, not Zbigniew – was also published during the period when Polish science fiction was developing.

### Jacek Dukaj
Jacek Dukaj is a Polish science fiction and fantasy writer, regarded among the most popular Polish contemporary science fiction authors. He is the recipient of numerous national and international literary prizes including the European Union Prize for Literature and Janusz A. Zajdel Award. Dukaj is one of the most well-known Polish fantasy writers and simultaneously one of the most frequently awarded. His writing focuses primarily on sci-fi – Dukaj often creates alternative cyberpunk realities.

The list of Zajdel Award winners includes Sapkowski, Dukaj, Huberath, Ziemkiewicz, but also Wit Szostak or Łukasz Orbitowski, whom we no longer associate with fantasy.

### Andrzej Ziemiański
Among the authors of the best Polish fantasy, Ziemiański is often mentioned with his cycle about Achaja – a warrior princess who is sent to the army by her stepmother to serve. Her life, though it is simultaneously a series of misfortunes, will be remembered for a long time in the history of this book world and will leave a mark on many heroes of Ziemiański's subsequent cycles.

Andrzej Ziemiański has been writing for quite some time, but gained great popularity mainly thanks to the three-volume Achaja series published at the beginning of the 21st century, as well as the recently completed five-volume continuation titled Monument to Empress Achaja.

### Łukasz Orbitowski
In 2017, he received the Zajdel Award for the story "Interview with Boruta". A writer of the young generation, who was already nominated for the Nike Literary Award, winner of the "Polityka" Passport and the Zajdel Award – we're talking about Łukasz Orbitowski. He is known for horror and fantasy books, but also for literary fiction.

Łukasz Orbitowski is a Polish writer specializing mainly in horror literature. Michał Cetnarowski, a respected publicist and editor of the Polish prose section of the cult monthly "Nowa Fantastyka", who in 2016 received the Janusz Zajdel Award for the story "Interview with Boruta" written together with Łukasz Orbitowski.

### Polish Sociological Science Fiction and Dune's Context

Sociological science fiction in the Polish People's Republic was a cult thing, and Janusz Zajdel is the most iconic figure of Polish sociological-political science fiction of the late PRL. Besides Lem, an important trend in Polish science fiction was sociological science fiction, which was initiated by Janusz A. Zajdel. This genre connects with scientific sci-fi, but focuses more on social changes and the influence of politics or technology on the life of individuals and masses.

Dune by Herbert was also published during this formative period of Polish science fiction, though the search results don't provide specific details about direct influence between Herbert's work and these Polish authors. However, the temporal overlap and the shared themes of sociological concerns in science fiction suggest a cultural dialogue between Western and Polish SF traditions during the 1970s and 1980s.

Among the Zajdel Award winners we find such diverse authors as Edmund Wnuk-Lipiński, Andrzej Sapkowski, Marek M. Huberath, Rafał Ziemkiewicz, Jacek Dukaj, Jarosław Grzędowicz, Anna Kańtoch, Maria Lidia Kossakowska, Łukasz Orbitowski, Andrzej Pilipiuk, showing the breadth and development of Polish science fiction influenced by Zajdel's sociological approach.
